title: Fix-and-Flip Investor’s Guide to Opportunity Cost
excerpt: Opportunity cost is a crucial factor when deciding between fix-and-flip projects and other real estate investments. Learn how to calculate and minimize opportunity cost to maximize your flipping profits.

content.text: What Is Opportunity Cost for Fix-and-Flippers?

Opportunity cost is the profit you miss out on by choosing one investment over another. For fix-and-flip investors, this means every decision—whether to buy, hold, or flip—comes with a trade-off. Understanding these trade-offs can help you make smarter, more profitable choices.
How to Calculate Opportunity Cost on Your Next Flip

For financial decisions, opportunity cost is straightforward: subtract the expected return of your chosen project from the return you could have earned on the best alternative. For example, if you expect an 18% ROI on a flip but could have earned 20% on a different project, your opportunity cost is 2%.

items: Holding Cash vs. Flipping: If you keep $50,000 in the bank instead of using it for a flip with a 15% annual ROI, you’re missing out on $7,500 per year.

Single-Family Flip vs. Multi-Family Project: Investing $100,000 in a 12-month flip with an 18% ROI vs. a 21-month multi-family deal with a 29% total ROI. Annualized, the flip returns 18% while the multi-family returns 16.57%. The opportunity cost of choosing the multi-family project is 1.43% per year.
Flipping vs. Passive Investing: Putting $75,000 into a hands-on flip with an 11% ROI vs. a syndication with an 18% ROI means a 7% opportunity cost if you stick with the flip.

content.text: Other Factors That Impact Your Flip’s Opportunity Cost

items: Risk: Flips can carry more risk than other investments. Higher risk may mean higher returns, but also higher stress and potential losses.
Liquidity: Flips tie up your capital for months. If another deal pops up, your money might be locked in.
Control: Flipping gives you full control over renovations and sales, but it also means more responsibility and time.
Time & Energy: Flipping is hands-on. Every hour spent managing contractors or staging homes is time you can’t spend on other deals.

content.text: How Flippers Can Minimize Opportunity Cost

items: Analyze every deal’s projected ROI and compare it to alternatives.
Factor in your time, risk tolerance, and how long your capital will be tied up.
Consider passive investments or partnerships to free up your time and diversify returns.
Stay liquid when possible, so you can jump on the best deals as they arise.

content.text: The best fix-and-flip investors maximize returns by making data-driven decisions and always considering what they might be missing out on. Keep opportunity cost top of mind, and you’ll flip smarter—and more profitably—every time.
